![Jeongneung Royal Tomb [UNESCO World Heritage] (ÏÑúÏö∏ Ï†ïÎ¶â(Ïã†ÎçïÏôïÌõÑ) [Ïú†ÎÑ§Ïä§ÏΩî ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÎ¨∏ÌôîÏú†ÏÇ∞])](/2022-08-04-1659634934496/2622291_image2_1.webp) ## Overview > Jeongneung Royal Tomb is the tomb of Queen Sindeok, the second wife of King Taejo (1392-1398), founder of the Joseon dynasty (1392-1910). The queen met a sudden death due to health complications. Although one of her sons was the crown prince, he was killed by a successive brother, Yi Bang-won, in order to obtain the throne. After Yi Bang-won rose to the throne as King Taejong, he relocated Queen Sindeok's tomb to outside of the city walls. ## Intro | | | | - | - | |infocenter:|‚Ä¢ 1330 Travel Hotline: +82-2-1330

* Visitors wearing hanbok.| |Available Facilities:|Convenience store, drinking fountain, rest area, etc.| |Restrooms:|Available| ## Detail Image ![/2022-08-04-1659634934496/720637_image2_1.webp](/2022-08-04-1659634934496/720637_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-08-04-1659634934496/720640_image2_1.webp](/2022-08-04-1659634934496/720640_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-08-04-1659634934496/720641_image2_1.webp](/2022-08-04-1659634934496/720641_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-08-04-1659634934496/720642_image2_1.webp](/2022-08-04-1659634934496/720642_image2_1.webp) ![/2022-08-04-1659634934496/720645_image2_1.webp](/2022-08-04-1659634934496/720645_image2_1.webp) ## Contact - [‚òéÔ∏è+82-2-914-5133](tel:+8229145133) - [üè†royaltombs.cha.go.kr](http://royaltombs.cha.go.kr) ```googleMap latitude: 37.6023505830 longitude: 127.0063452451 title: 116, Arirang-ro 19-gil, Seongbuk-gu, Seoul ``` ## Directions [Bus]
Sungshin Women's University Station (Seoul Subway Line 4), Exit 6.
Take Bus No. 1012, 1014, or 1212 and get off at Arirang Market Bus Stop.
Walk for approx. 5-10 min.

data.title: Jeongneung Royal Tomb  [UNESCO World Heritage] (ÏÑúÏö∏ Ï†ïÎ¶â(Ïã†ÎçïÏôïÌõÑ) [Ïú†ÎÑ§Ïä§ÏΩî ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÎ¨∏ÌôîÏú†ÏÇ∞])
data.description: Jeongneung Royal Tomb is the tomb of Queen Sindeok, the second wife of King Taejo (1392-1398), founder of the Joseon dynasty (1392-1910). The queen met a sudden death due to health complications. Although one of her sons was the crown prince, he was killed by a successive brother, Yi Bang-won, in order to obtain the throne. After Yi Bang-won rose to the throne as King Taejong, he relocated Queen Sindeok's tomb to outside of the city walls.
data.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Namsan Seoul Tower (ÎÇ®ÏÇ∞ÏÑúÏö∏ÌÉÄÏõå)
dataList.description: Namsan Seoul Tower was the first multipurpose tower to be established in Korea, effectively incorporating a sightseeing observatory to a broadcasting tower. For the past 40 years, Namsan Seoul Tower has served as an iconic landmark of Korea and a representative tourist attraction. The tower's observatory offers an unobstructed view of the whole city, allowing it to become one of the all-time favorite attractions of Seoul citizens as well as domestic and international tourists. Another highlight of the tower is the Namsan Cable Car. The cable car began its operation in 1962, transferring passengers from the foot of the mountain to the base of the tower. Shuttle buses to the Namsan Cable Car from downtown Seoul are also available for visitors' convenience.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Namsan Outdoor Botanical Garden (ÎÇ®ÏÇ∞ ÏïºÏô∏ÏãùÎ¨ºÏõê)
dataList.description: Namsan Outdoor Botanical Garden opened its doors on February 18, 1997 in Hannam-dong, where the residential complex for foreigners once stood before it was demolished in 1994. Covering an area of around 59 „é°, it is divided into 13 themed gardens with a total 117,132 plants from 269 species. Among this diversity, 60,912 plants from 129 species are tree types and 56,220 plants from 140 species are grass types.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Namsan Octagonal Pavilion (ÎÇ®ÏÇ∞ ÌåîÍ∞ÅÏ†ï)
dataList.description: Originally known as Unamjeong Pavilion, the pavilion was built in 1959 to commemorate Rhee Syngman. It was demolished by the 4.19 movement in 1960 and was rebuilt on November 11, 1968. This pavilion now sits atop Namsan Mountain, with views covering the entirety of Seoul below. As it is a prime spot to view the first sunrise of the year, the annual sunrise festival takes place every New Year's Day.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Namsan Cable Car (ÎÇ®ÏÇ∞ ÏºÄÏù¥Î∏îÏπ¥)
dataList.description: Namsan Cable Car provides a panoramic view of downtown Seoul. The cable car has been in operation for over 40 years, taking tourists and residents alike to Namsan Seoul Tower, one of the most representative tourist attractions in the city.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Nakseonjae Hall (ÎÇôÏÑ†Ïû¨)
dataList.description:
Located inside Changdeokgung Palace, Nakseonjae Hall is a one-story structure built in ikgong style (bird wing-shaped eaves placed on top of the pillars) with a hip tiled and gable roof. It has 6 kan in the front and 2 kan (traditional unit of measurement of the space between pillars) to the sides. It originally belonged to the nearby Changgyeonggung Palace, but came to be considered a part of Changdeokgung Palace in more recent years.

The hall was constructed in 1846 (12th year of King Heonjong‚Äôs reign) and it is collectively called Nakseonjae together with the adjacent Seokbokheon Hall and Sugangjae Hall.

Behind the building is a flower garden made of stacked large stones. The chimney, the flowers, and the oddly shaped stones harmoniously blend into one another to create an outstanding landscape gardening.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Naksan Park (ÎÇôÏÇ∞Í≥µÏõê)
dataList.description: Naksan Park gets its name from its camel hump-like appearance. The mountain is a solid granite bedrock. The Joseon royal family enjoyed the natural beauty of the granite mountain, but during the Japanese Colonial Period, a hasty manner of urban planning resulted in the demolition of most parts of the mountain.  In an effort to save the remaining green belts, Naksan was designated as a park on June 10, 2002.  Located in the center of the Seoul, this historical and beautiful park allows its visitors to view the magnificence of the entire city.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: N. Olive Esthetic (Ïï§Ïò¨Î¶¨Î∏å ÏóêÏä§ÌÖåÌã±)
dataList.description: Located on the first underground floor of Times Square in Yeongdeungpo, N. Olive Esthetic is a spa and beauty care shop. It offers professional nail art, hand and foot care and skin and full body therapies. Services include specialty packages like the Oil Candle Therapy (aroma oil produced from melted candles) using beauty care items from France. Every service includes a foot massage.
dataList.author: korea-tour
